title: Songs from Life
transcript: I'd like to thank everybody for being here and everybody that people here for inviting me to speak about my work. I just want to just quickly say that I had the opportunity of meeting in Andrade after a group show we were in together at in Philadelphia at the Locks Gallery and the opportunity to meet her with the dinner afterwards. And it was a great opportunity and I remember that we sat next to each other in the restaurant. She was really just a very, I can say, just her spirit was extremely generous and she gave me space. And I didn't know, I knew of her work before meeting her but not as much as I do now. And what I was impressed with is that she gave me space and this is an artist who is very, very important, very profound. And I think we're going to learn a lot more about her and the world is going to learn a lot more about her with shows like this. But as I looked at her syllabi and different student coursework that she put together and looked at that research, I saw the mind of a genius and a great mind, a huge mind. And someone who was really able to utilize teaching as a means of growing her work and of building the work through the help of her students and the students would learn it along the way. But to look at that resource material, that source materials to know how intensely intelligent and ambitious this artist is. And so I want to preface my talk with this information to say that the ways in which artists can bring their information, their story, their history to the practice is very profound and never really seen by the audience. They just see the finished thing and they can make their judgments and statements from that. But it's really very important to understand all those little things and big things that come into making. And you definitely see in that room that room is packed. It's like a box that's like pressed. So I would have present some images real quick for you guys to speak about my own process and just to say that I feel just moved by her sense of generosity and the fact that she gave me that space that evening and a person who could have consumed all the space that evening was that was that kind. So this is worked on specifically focusing on from a period of 20 to 2021 through to the present. I'm a painter. My practice has evolved over the years where I'm looking at space color and I'm thinking about my experience and my upbringing as an African and Nigerian. And these paintings really started from when I started to understand fully understood what I wanted to do. I wanted to create a space that would be that would exist before language. And that was my situational understanding of that was because I watched a lot of TV as a kid that space before the image became clear, that test band pattern space before. This doesn't kids today don't have this but this this test band pattern that's exploded the screen right before you saw an image which is in my mind language. So that space is really important for me as a as an African as a black person in this world because as I say as an African and as a black person in this world I'm defining myself and then you can have your constructs that you place on top of me because I just said those things. But this is the world we live in so I was wanting to unknowing at the time the space before language where essentially it's it's another idea of freedom or freedom is very open but another space to understand or maybe experienced freedom. So in this case in this work this was a piece called walls of change made at the Philadelphia Museum of Art. It was a piece that was coming out of the pandemic and political climate and this is the installation process of putting that piece together. And I'm sharing these resource images similar to what we see upstairs with the kind of of research that Edna is putting together in her in her production. This was what I was inspired by the walls of change being the museum walls. The museum was basically acted as a backdrop for all this activity in the city during this time all these different protests all these different actions. And for me the formations of people in this space were my way of understanding the formations of the space in which I used for my painting for my installation. Looking at how people are organizing themselves how movement is occurring and what's going on and it's just to say that source material can come from anything and from anywhere and this is what was my particular motivation for this work at the Philadelphia Museum of Art. It's very interesting in ways in which things change and things stay the same. And to see this at this time and to think that this was of that time and to know what we're going through now is to see that things can continue and struggle continues and that was part of the element of that work as well. This is a piece called Surrounding that's at the University of Iowa Stanley Museum of Art. This piece inaugurated the museum's renovations and it was up in conjunction with the Jackson Pollock painting mural that was brought back to its home there. This is a special place for me as well because my parents went to school here as graduate students. My father studied printmaking and painting before going to Indiana University to study with Roy Seiber, the first Africanist in America to become an art historian there. So Surrounding is really coming from a collection of my sensibility, my sensing color and my sensing space and just extrapolating from my experience there. This is a piece I did at the Dallas Cowboys Stadium, the AT&T Stadium. This is a different kind of client. I wanted to show this in conjunction with the art institutional work because when I'm working and doing these installations there's a different person that's coming to ask me to do these things and it's a different kind of experience from the other. This is the completed work at this time. I was asked to do two sides of the stadium. There was a little apprehension with the use of my color. So they decided to only do one side of the stadium and they love this but I'm still waiting for them to possibly ask me to do the other side of the stadium. There's also a very interesting thing that happened here. We don't have time for the story but I just wanted to mention that. These are the different sequences. I'm very interested in ways that art can work in spaces and it's very different from the idea of thinking of the white cube or a gallery space work functions in a way that you have a bench, you have space and whatnot. I like the way in which art work can activate a space, become active and activate the audience in different ways. It's not to say that it's a problem because there's an obstacle in front of it but how does the work engage the space and allow you to become more aware of what you're doing as you're there. This edge is very important to me because it objectifies the painting and makes it like a thing in the middle of this space that is a thing as well. This is a wall I did at Astor Park in Columbus, Ohio for the Columbus Cruise Stadium, the soccer team there, the pieces called Interplay. I was thinking about the colors of the team, yellow and black and the space between white and black as let's say the extremes of value. That was a certain kind of aesthetic concern that allowed me to ultimately realize this particular piece. It was really quite difficult because when I'm thinking of color, color is not something that's just random and randomly selected. Actually, this is actually a very difficult thing because I had to think of a color range between yellow and black that could exist and be reasonably felt and understood between yellow and black. It was just really daunting and it took me a while to get to it but I think it worked out. Also, I wanted to think about the way in which this activity of soccer, the field challenge in sport came into the design of the work. This is the last series of images showing the digital renderings of the installation. I was in a conversation with the museum essentially two years before we actually implemented the work and it took me again a while to make these drawings, collect the drawings together. Once they were approved, in my sense, I approved them, I showed them to curator, then I redrew everything again to really finalize it for us to be able to do this work. Then there's another layer of work which I'm not showing that goes to my assistants that put that up on the wall. This is a sense of the client has to come in because these are expensive. They have to actually understand what you're doing. I think it's really great to actually see these things because we get a sense of what in a way in which the artist in the studio has to learn through that time. I can learn through this time what the work is going to do and how it's going to move and function. But there was a lot of hours of drawing and then color selection before we get to this initial space here which is now the physical space in the museum. The wall that's overhanging was really a stressful wall because we could only do that at night after the museum closed with the scissor lift. Because the timeframe of when we had to do it, this is a museum that is an organic entity that never sleeps. It's always functioning and doing something so there were many days in which we couldn't work at all because they were dedicated to other schedule events. But if we miss painted any of these shapes, we would have lost days and which would have put us out of schedule because we needed to fix the entire space within a given time. But it was really great to have the installation during the day with the audience there because they interacted, they loved it. And that's very important part of this project as well where people get to see a painting made in front of them. They get basically being in the artist studio but the artist studio is in the public space. And then this is the last piece just called Skyway. I completed an installation which is not here because I did it in 2019, 2020 at the Penn Medicine Pavilion which is now called the Clifton Center. This is again a digital rendering, not a rhino model but a digital rendering of my drawing filled with color. The colors I selected for this I was thinking of the hospital and the ways in which I wanted to open up essentially a new window in this really tight hallway space and bring a different kind of light to that hospital. So this is the finished piece, the day it was finished with the Cicerolyphs still there but it's up now. And if you were to visit, well on good terms if you're ever to visit this hospital, you would see that it's part of another section of the hospital where there are two different installations going up the escalator and down another hallway. And so this is the third installment. Thank you.

title: Octagon Study 78
transcript: I am so incredibly delighted to see all of you who have gathered with us for this conversation, and I want to open by echoing Sarah's thanks to all who have supported us. One of the most fulfilling parts and privileges of this career is being surrounded by creative minds engaged in thinking, discussion, and those who are committed to a lifetime of continual learning and growth. A sense of this spirit, the idea of artworks that were themselves exercises in looking and thinking is what first drew me to the art of Edna Andrade. Over the years that we have spent over the years that we have spent thumbing through her archives and studio files and of talking with the many members of the Philadelphia Arts community who were her students, who knew her through the city's arts institutions, and who admired the way her presence and practice gave them an anchor in its arts community. I have come to admire that Edna's greatest legacy may have been the way that she brought that energy of learning into all her relationships. The QR code on the screen is also on the opening panel of the exhibition text, and from it you can link to excerpts of Andrade's oral history with the archives of an American art, video clips of the artist at work in her studio, and the voices of the artists and museum professionals or a few who were shaped by their encounters with her and who as a group span generations. Tonight's program is not about Edna Andrade, but we developed it guided by her spirit. From her earliest days Edna pictured herself as an artist. She was fiercely committed to her artistic practice to building a career as an independent artist and to lifelong learning through conversation, community, and thinking across both cultural and disciplinary ways of learning. Before we begin this conversation, I want to offer a very brief introduction to the artist whose work has inspired this gathering. Born Edna Wright in 1917 in Port Smith, Virginia to a middle-class family who encouraged her interest in the arts. In 1934 she would enroll at the University of Pennsylvania to pursue a formal education in the arts. There she also completed her postgraduate studies at the Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts in 1938. Her education was about drawing from observation, a traditional academic training, creating convincingly faithful renderings of the life models as we see in this student drawing or student exercise on the left. And it's this interest, this practice of looking closely and drawing from observation, is a skill that she would continue into her middle age and beyond. From there, from after graduating, she began her first position as an educator, moving to New Orleans where she would teach visual arts at Newcombe College, the women's coordinate of Tulane University. Shortly after her arrival, the department would welcome a new chair, Robin Field, who arrived from his studies at Harvard's Graduate School of Design, and would transform the curriculum by introducing the lessons of the Bauhaus Foundation's course. From there on out, Andrade would think of art as well as her pedagogy as a process of inquiry, and the student exercise from one of Robin Field's foundations classes at Newcombe College, that he later donated to the Bush Risinger Museum, and is part of the Harvard Art Museum collections, and on the right, one of Andrade's studies in color and formed, inspired by one of her great Bauhaus influences, Joseph Albers. In 1941, when she returned to Philadelphia, where she would remain for the remainder of her career and life, she would apply her study of geometric compositions to designs for works for public and commercial arts commissions. And by the late 1950s, indeed, she had returned to the classroom and would remain an educator for the next four plus decades, influencing generations of artists in the Philadelphia Arts communities. An influential intellectual community that informed her work in these years was the group Form Forum, you see a flyer of theirs on the far right. This interdisciplinary slion convened artists, architects, scientists, and engineers to share their scholarship, believing firmly that they would learn that their studies in these various fields would inform one another. Modelled after the Harvard MIT filamorfs, this group, the Form Forum, also hosted guests from Cambridge, and we, in fact, have a flyer of the, for the guest lecture, when Arthur Loeb was the guest lecturer. Another bridge between Edna and Harvard, though she never was herself, a scholar here, was her close friendship with Anne Ting. Ting was one of the first female graduates of the Harvard's Graduate School of Design, and a part of the Philadelphia's Form Forum. Ting's study of space frames structures would become fundamental to her architectural practice, and we see it here across the ceiling expanse of Yale University's art gallery. A structure that would give new inspiration to how Edna approached the drawing of deep space, or illusionistic space, within her line drawings, and that would inform how she would place these geometries into built space in her public commissions, and here we see a marble mosaic piece at the Philadelphia free library that uses that same structural form. Whether the facets of a crystal or the branching patterns of a tree, Edna's compositions, the foundation of Edna's compositions was always, however, a study of the natural world. Geometry was, for Edna, a mathematics of describing systems in nature, and from her student days forward, she would love to travel, and as she travel, find different geometries in cultural context distant from her own. One of my very favorite drawings in the show is this precise architectural sketch of an observatory she discovered in John Termontar, an influential trip she took in 1984 to India. The structure itself is a form of geometry, it is a geometric form, and as we see it in Andrade's sketches, it bisects the landscape creating new vantage points and new ways of seeing. In her own practice, these were only jumping off points, and she would take them and interpret them to create these new compositions or new ways of thinking through geometry. In the end, Edna was most recognized for her paintings, and there are two in the exhibition upstairs. However, it's in her drawings that we see her mind at work. The exhibition itself takes its title from a quote from her teaching notes. In these teaching notes, she herself speaks about the importance of imagination. As a faculty, as she says, for structuring life and organizing relationships and making mental images, but as a faculty that itself is never static. It has been an honor to learn through the act of looking at Andrade's practice, and my learning has been deepened profoundly through the opportunity of conversation. And for that, and much more that has brought us here, I'm indebted to the exhibition's co-curator, Madeline Murphy Turner, who will introduce tonight's speakers.

Edvard Mung, technically speaking, featured collaborative research here at the Harveter Museums. By using the latest technology available, we took a really deep look at Mung's creative process. Mung is known as one of the most innovative and influential artists of the 20th century. title: , Title: Carving Out Time
transcript: Hi everyone and welcome to the opening of the Special Exhibition Latoya M Hobbes its time. This event marks the beginning of the scholarship and academic discourse around Hobbes' work that will take place here at Harvard while the show is on view. Professor Jones, Kayla Jackson and Latoya Hobbes have prepared every date remarks to initiate our conversation today and to jumpstart the work we will all do collectively in our shared conversations and reflections on the prints titled Carving Out Time. So let's begin. Our first speaker today is Javana Jones who is an assistant professor of African American literature and culture at Boston College. She teaches and researches black visual culture, black feminist criticism and the built environment. Her writing has been published in aperture, souls, Kalaloo, Southern cultures and by the Museum of Contemporary Art Chicago. Javana is currently working on a book entitled The Last Thanksgiving at West Fretland Square. It tells the story of her grandmother and 11 other elderly black women who fought to save their brownstone apartment building in the midst of Boston's gentrifying south end in the 1980s. Can't wait to read that. She has also worked on the visual and architectural study of black women's rooming houses across the United States, homes that were organized at the turn of the 20th century to house black women migrating to new cities for work, education and fresh beginnings. Javana is the recipient of fellowships from the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation, the Edmund J. Safra Center for Ethics and Dartmouth College. She holds her PhD in MA from Harvard University and her BA from Emory University. Please join me in welcoming Professor Jones to the podium. I'm just going to say this, my heart is beating out of my chest and it's weird because I went here for many years. So I'm like, this is home. Why is my heart beating out of my chest? I realize this is the first time I've actually had to talk about an artist work in front of the artist, not just the artist, her partner, not just her partner, they're two children. And so this is why I work on our ancestors. And as much as I love contemporary art, this is new for me. And so I want to frame this as I told you, Latoya earlier, that this is a meditation on I think reflection with how I felt when I be held your work last week. So thank you Elizabeth for this invitation and early conversations about Latoya's work over Zoom and during install. Thank you Kayla for being my art history homey and an ongoing thought partner in black feminist art. And thank you again Latoya, who I refer to you as Hobbs for the rest of this. For your generosity of skill and intimacy in your work, I'm honored to be in conversation with you about it. When I enter the gallery to see Hobbs monumental prints based on her woodcuts, I shrink. The precision of Latoya Hobbs hand overwhelmed me. I tried to describe the sensations my older sister jazz on FaceTime yesterday. I tried to capture the sheer volume of marks and carvings required to replicate and reimagine her family's living spaces and routines. Okay so on the video they showed, I started. She's like right in front of the wood, face right there, has this little scalpel tool she uses to carve each mark out of the wood. All of them jazz, all the marks. I repeat shaking the phone. I remember Hobbs has collaborators of course, so multiple hands made this work possible. From her partner, artist, Eris and Jack, to her kids, to her printers from Big Ink, many hands were involved. Still, the image I hold close is that still from the video. Hobbs face so close to the material, the smell and taste of dust and ink. The artist speaks to us over the studio footage. Just as working people, parents, whatever your walk of life is, she says, we all have to have these days in negotiations where we ask, how am I going to get all of these things done with the time that I have? Carving out time is a series of scenes depicting slices of this family's life, the time they make for each other and spend together. But carving out time is also Hobbs offering, from the sacred time she spends with herself within and close to the work. That we might recognize a black woman's household work as both life sustaining and creative was precisely what Alice Walker wanted for her own mother. In her seminal 1972 essay in search of our mother's gardens, Walker writes about the creative life force of black mothers, grandmothers and great-grandmothers, exploited for their domestic labor and leaving their artistic marks, quote, in the only material she could afford and in the only medium her position in society allowed her to use, end quote. She saw how this bird and surfaced in her sharecropper mother in fields from before sun up to late night. She writes that her mother never had a moment to sit down undisturbed, to peruse her own private thoughts. Something always interrupted her, either work or the inquiries of her children, Walker remembering that she's one of them. So Walker went in search of the secret of what fed her mother from whom so much had been required. She wanted to see how her mother indulged her vibrant creative spirit, she says, and where that spirit pops out. It is only in adulthood when Walker finds her mother studio. She writes, the artist that was and is my mother showed itself to me only after many years. This is what I finally noticed. My mother adorned with flowers, whatever shabby house we were forced to live in, and not just your typical straggly country strands of zinnia, either. No, she planted ambitious gardens and still does with over 50 different varieties of plants that bloom profusely. When did her mother find the time, I wonder? Walker continues, before she left home for the fields, she watered her flowers, chopped up the grass, and laid out new beds. When she returned from the fields, she might divide clumps of bulbs, dig a cold pit, uproot and replant roses, or prune branches from her taller bushes or trees, until night came and it was too dark to see. Walker describes her mother's tending with such microscopic detail that the garden becomes a world unto itself, damp and unwieldy and curious to her mother's hands. Walker writes, whatever she planted grew as if by magic, and her fame as a grower of flowers spread over three counties. The daughter remembers the people coming to enjoy what her mother had made. She says, I remember people coming to my mother's yard to be given cuttings from her flowers. I hear again the praise showered on her because whatever rocky soil she landed on, she turned into a garden. A garden so brilliant with colors, so original in its design, so magnificent with life and creativity that to this day people drive by our house in Georgia, perfect strangers and imperfect strangers, and ask to stand or walk among my mother's art. Even with all of this external validation of her gardening craft, Alice Walker notices that it is only when her mother is working in the garden that she is radiant. She says she's radiant almost to the point of being invisible, except as creator. I pause here in my reading. Walker says it's only in the garden when her mother appears radiant like this, which kind of makes me sad. It makes me wish her mother could look and feel just as radiant elsewhere in her life, in her home with her family. Maybe she did, but Walker couldn't see that multiplicity as a child. Creative solitude is what excites the writer Alice Walker that we know. The solitude is what excites her the most, reminds her of what she herself has inherited and orchestrated her life around. I hear Walker's black feminist thinking echo in Hobbs scenes, which begin in the home and arrive in the studio, another kind of garden. Hobbs gives us a third option beyond the duality of sacrificial motherhood and solitary artistry. She makes art that can't be held without holding all of her and her people too. Art that bears an integrated black woman self, supported, safe, and seen. How thrilling it must be for the children, Aidean Theo, to know that the same hands that pull them up onto the bed, turn their heads back to the home school lesson, bring dinner to the table and hold the book at bedtime, made these carvings right here, taking up all this space in places, miles, and miles from home. Those same hands here, and scene one, reaching up towards morning light. Hobbs holds a moment of inner respite in her face. Her eyes are closed. title: October's Gone...Goodnight
transcript: This is Barclay Hendrix's October's Gone Good Night from 1973. It's a portrait of a woman from three angles. What I'm doing right now is removing two layers of varnish on the figures because the varnish has discolored with time. And the discoloration created a much darker white tone that's almost warmer in a way than the background. The varnish, when it first went on, would have given the figure an added layer of sheen and saturated and deepened the skin in hair tones. Having this art go out in a state where it can be enjoyed the way it was supposed to be is what gives meaning to my work. My name is Ellen Davis, and I'm the associate painting's conservator here at the Strasse Center at the Harvard Art Museums.

title: Fragmentary portrait of a man

Her masterpiece, The Life of the Mind, her most profound reflection on thinking about thinking takes three main questions as points of departure. What are we doing when we do nothing but think? To engage in the activity of thinking, one must withdraw from the world's irons in cist into a private space or rather an intimate space where a thinker can be alone with oneself and in dialogue with oneself. I believe that space and the object of that dialogue can be found in Dutch art of the 17th century. The German philosopher Friedrich Higel would have considered courtes still lives and the works of 17th century Dutch painting in general to be thought objects. In his lectures in aesthetics delivered in Berlin in the 1820s, you rise with barely contained enthusiasm about the philosophical dimension of the highly realistic representations of daily life, so typical of Dutch visual culture. For Higel, these little pictures breathed the spirit of freedom that permeated the Dutch Republic, following its heartworm independence from mighty Spain during the 80s war and its liberation from Catholic domination. In the depiction of ordinary things, Higel saw evidence of a nation that had detached itself from its historical course by making contemporary life a subject worthy of representation. Unlike the religious art of southern Europe or allegories glorifying monarchs at the French and English courts which subjected viewers to a particular ideology, Dutch art had freedom itself from such constraints by insisting that people should see the world for themselves. It manifested the spirit of self-consciousness by presenting to its citizens an image of themselves and the life they led, not that there is a description of the world, but rather an object of contemplation. Still life painting in particular had freedom itself from the incumbrances of narrative or religious meaning and could instead present the world as an object of contemplation. Higel is not interested in actual ordinary things because the world is filled with such objects, but in the way their appearance had been captured in painting through the play of light falling onto them as he sees exemplified in the work of Willem Kulf.
